At 22:45 25/06/2004, you wrote:
>hey,
>
>that make sense. does the level of strategy have to do with the
>number of inputs and outputs (ie does more inputs and outputs imply
>greater strategy)? also, how do you know when they agents have maxed
>out the strategy of the environment?

It's not so much the shear size of inputs and outputs, it's a deeper 
relationship i.e. the "richness" of the environment.  For example, an agent 
could have a 1000x1000 array of inputs, but if they represent a million 
unrelated channels, then the agent has less it can learn than if they 
represent one high-resolution video feed.

<<Not that this is currently a practical problem size :) >>

Then, there's a second barrier, of the "evolvability" of the agent, e.g. if 
the gaps between functional solutions are too wide, then no amount of time 
or population-size will make the jump into the complicated stuff.

<<  Incidentally this suggests a simple model for why populations pause 
longest between big fitness jumps:

1) and fitness jump available in the local solution-space will be made on a 
faster time scale
2) longer jumps across solution space will occur at frequencies with some 
sort of inverse relation to the jump length
3) long jumps may land in the foothills of another "mountain" on the 
solution space (the parameter search community generally regard increasing 
quality as downwards, so "basin" is the more common term...)
4) but you will only ever see the results of that jump if the mountain 
arrived on is higher than the previous equilibrium, in which case the 
mutant species will rapidly run up hill as far as it can and take over the 
population (or at least the number-one spot)

Thus long pauses occur before big jumps because they are the delay after 
all available "easy" improvements have been made, but while we are waiting 
for a single low probability event. >>

         Ian Badcoe
